Award.AwardTitle: An integral approach to reveal the identity of light elements in the Earth's core
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Earth has an iron-dominant core that consists of a liquid outer core and a solid inner core at the center. The Earth's core is the engine of the planet, generating global magnetic field and driving large-scale plate motions on the surface through mantle convection. A better understanding of its chemical composition will help us to understand how the engine works. Current knowledge of the core implies that incorporation of light elements (such as sulfur, oxygen, silicon) in the iron core is necessary to explain the observed density and velocities of the core, but there is considerable controversy over the precise identity of the light alloying elements in the core because it is experimentally challenging to precisely measure the density and sound velocity of the iron alloys under core conditions.

In this study, I am outlining a new approach to narrow down the identity of the light elements in the core by combining dynamic and static compression experiments. The proposed experiments will yield new density and velocity data obtained by shock compression and static compression in the high-temperature diamond-anvil cell. Specifically, I propose four types of experiments, (1) shock compression to obtain densities of Fe-Si alloys, (2) in-situ x-ray diffraction measurements in high-temperature diamond-anvil cell to obtain P-V-T data, (3) measurements of the sound velocities of the alloys by shockwave experiments, and (4) measurements of the compressional-wave velocity of alloys in the high-temperature diamond-anvil cell by inelastic x-ray scattering technique. This is our first attempt to integrate results from dynamic and static compression experiments on the same samples, which allows us to obtain complementary data over a wide P-T range and to establish self-consistent database from two independent high-pressure experiments. The new data on Fe-Si alloys will be integrated into our existing data to make comprehensive models of the core.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The Earth has an iron (Fe) dominant core that consists of a liquid outer core and a solid inner core at the center. The Earth’s core is the engine of the planet, generating global magnetic field and driving large-scale plate motions on the surface through mantle convection. A better understanding of its chemical composition will help us to understand how the engine works. The goal of this study is to determine the role of sulfur (S) and silicon (Si) in the Fe-dominant core. We use static and dynamic compression techniques to obtain the density and sound velocity of Fe, Fe-S alloy and Fe-Si alloy. The experimental data are then compared to seismic observations to infer the S and Si contents in the core. We have successfully determined the density and sound velocity of pure Fe, Fe-11wt%S alloy and Fe-9wt%Si alloy under Earth's core conditions. The data obtained using multiple high-pressure techniques are complementary each other and represent the highest precision, which provides a tight constraint on the composition of the Earth's core.

Broader Impacts: My research is an integral part of my long-term effort to address broad issues in deep Earth study at the interface of geophysics, petrology, mineral physics, and geochemistry. The research directly resulted in five peer-reviewed papers in Geophysical Research Letter, Earth Planetary Science Letter, and American Mineralogist. We disseminate the research results through national and international conferences effectively and timely. The program also supports an active postdoctoral program, trained 2 postdoctoral associates through this project. The project has provided opportunities for international collaborations that involve in young scientists. Through the project we have developed new dynamic and static high-pressure techniques that benefit a broad high-pressure research community. The project has made positive contributions to the user community and enhanced the productivity of the large user facilities.
